Posts.Content: Hi Jules, I had the LD Back Flap Reconstruction last July.. I asked my Surgeon to try to do it without putting in an implant (not that I did not want one but just thought it was something else to go wrong !!). Anyway Op was 8 hours long.. I woke up feeling not bad. Was attached to a Morphine Pump - which I only ever pressed once ( when I got confused with light switch lol).. I can honestly say whilst I was obviously aware of the operation I never had any real pain. Was only on Paracetomol.. Was in hospital for 6 days. I was a bit shaky afterwards and it took me a while to get my strength back. I had 3 drains in.. Two were taken out before I left hospital and remainder was in for 7 weeks !!  which did drive me mad must admit. But I put it in a bag and once I felt better put it over my shoulder and was out and about.. As said before you do have a large scar across your back.. I had some problems with scar tissue so was reffered to Physio which helped a lot.. To be honest I dont even think about it now..  In Dec 2011 I had a reduction, uplift on other breast,and nipple reconstruction. Was really pleased with results but was a bit disappointed that breasts were still significantly different size. When I saw my Surgeon he explained he could only reduce the other breast so much or it would go out of shape. So now I am booked to have an implant fitted in April.. I am quite surprised you have been told you cant have implant as you have had RT. I was advised not to have it before RT but was fine afterwards. I have never regretted having this operation... Anything you want to ask please do.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: Hi Vicky, I had my last chemo on 4th May, and then started 15 sessions of radiotherapy 3 weeks later. Compared to chemo R/T is a doddle !!! apart from being tired I had no side effects at all. I used the aqueous cream dilligently and also only used Simple Soap.. Worse thing really was the hanging about.. I changed my appointments till about 15.00 everyday as previously I was going at 13.00 so it limited what I could do in the morning.. There seemed to be a quicker turn around later.. I did find that my arm ached a bit (as it has to be in one position) mind you I could recite the measurements after a while !!!! Went back to work in July and am feeling very very well.. Best of luck Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Radio therapy - cream/oil?

Posts.Content: Hi Nain, I was diagnosed in Nov 2009, I had to have  a CT Scan before the operation. I got myself into such a state.. Was convinced it had spread and felt dizzy and sick all the time. I spoke to my BCN and she said "it was shock" after diagnosis.  Once I had results of CT (all clear) I felt much better.. You may well have an ear infection but the mind can do some strange things.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: spining room and nausea

Posts.Content: Hi Anne I had FEC Chemo in 2010. Although I only live 10 mins from hospital it took 3 -4 hours for effects to kick in. Hope you get on ok, for me it really was not as bad as anticipated. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Chemo starting next Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera I had MX in Dec 2009 followed by chemo & RT. I had a reconstruction op last year. The week before the MX I was in a terrible state, convinced it had spread everywhere. When I woke up from op all I felt was relief it was out of me. As others have said this really is the worse time. Take care Debra x
Posts.Title: Mx operation

Posts.Content: Hi Chelle Hope all goes well tomorrow. I had chemo in 2010 (3 of FEC & 3 of Tax). Yes I felt exactly the same, scared but happy with the treatment starting. I had a good reaction to chemo, felt grotty first week but quickly improved and by 3rd week I was here there and everywhere !!! Just listen to your body and if you need to rest try to.. I used to drive to hospital and back. Did not used to kick in till few hours after. I am sure you have been told but FEC makes your urine go red for first couple of days ( just so you don't freak). I used to have a light meal before I went and just soup later. Remember to take the anti-sickness meds (even if you don't feel sick). Good idea to write stuff down, tell Doc your side effects and he can give you something or your meds may need tweaking. I did lose my hair after 2nd chemo but although I was dreading it,it was not as bad as expected. In fact when my own hair grew I used to miss that wig when I had to get up 30mins earlier to blow dry my hair !! I would have your holiday in Devon, but maybe best to wait till treatment is over before going abroad. Good luck, and let me know if you want any more info. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: 1st chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Jan Have also added you as friend on FB. Can you add me to group Regards Debra
Posts.Title: facebook

Posts.Content: Hi My Surgeon is a bit obsessive with his drains !!!!  I was always told that the drain has to lose less than 40 ml before it came out. When I had the mastectomy it was in for 2 weeks. I did develop a Seroma and just saw my BC and she drained it. She told me that whilst its not urgent to have it drained its better to.  When I had Recon, drain was in for 7 weeks !!!!  mind you did not have any Seromas afterwards !!! Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Share your experience with a seronoma

Posts.Content: Hi Roscoe & Jo My name is Debra, I was diagnosed in Nov 09 and had a mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy. I finished treatment in June of this year. They took 9 lymph nodes and 2 were shown to have slight invasion. Although surgeon was happy all the cancer had been removed my Oncologist advised me to have a course of chemo "just to mop up any little blighters" followed by a 15 day course of radiotherapy. Doc said the radiotherapy was again more of a precaution, to the chest area. I was advised against having the reconstruction at same time as mainly as you say the radiotherapy can damage it. In fact when you sign the consent form for R/T it does say that.  I was also advised to wait at least a year after treatment as Docs had found your body copes with it better. I am hoping to have the back flap reconstruction next year. The worse part for me was leading up to the operation. Once it was over I felt it was"out of me". I started chemo 6 weeks later (6 sessions every 3 weeks). I was very fortunate in my reaction to chemo as I recovered very well. R/T was a doddle compared to chemo !!!  I went back to work in July and have been fine. I wont go on and on but anything you want to ask please dont hesitate. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: decisions decisions.......

Posts.Content: Hi Zoe, I lost my Dad to cancer in 2004..  In 2009 I found lump in my breast..  I was so worried about how this would affect my Mum that I did not tell her till I was diagnosed.. She was so upset when I finally told her that I had not confided in her before.. I did go on my own to appointment and that was not great.. As your Mum is a 20 year survivor I am sure she will just want to support you.. good luck Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Worried about appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Cookie I had chemo last year (after mastectomy)..My hair came out after 2nd chemo.. It just started coming out in strands, but when I washed it the whole side just came away.. It was the wose time I think.. I had a wig (which for me was the best thing). I was recomended to have the wig trimmed by a specialist.. Now the advantages !!  a free "brazilian cut" on my lady garden (that comment made me laugh !!) no shaving of legs and underarms.. Got the ladies on the Estee Lauder counter to show me how to draw in my eyebrows.Saved me a fortune on hair products !!!  i did lose my eyelash's and noticed my eyes would water a lot.. If I wore sunglass's when sunny it was fine.. My hair has now grown back, have just had my 3rd haircut !!  must admit I do moan sometimes about having to get up earlier to blowdry my hair !! Take care Regards Debra Was
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Sqirrell. I had FEC in 2010. Had 3 FEC & 3 TAX. I know lots of people have an awful reaction to chemo especially TAX. But I was pretty much ok. Had no,losing of nails, pain etc. I did have a sore mouth but used to have a swig of the antiseptic mouthwash everyday. Found I could not drink coffee or tea but found Options White Chocolate drink was nice. Hope you get on ok. Regard Debra xx
Posts.Title: 2 more FEC then 4 tax, i am in pieces worrying

Posts.Content: Hi Ali I did not have the cold cap and lost my hair after 2nd chemo.. Hopefully you should keep yours !!! I went to Debenhams to the Estee Lauder Counter.. They were fantastic, showed me how to do my eyebrows (which I had lost)..  I also used the Yves ST Laurent Touche Eclait under my eyes as they did not look great after chemo.. Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy I had chemo last year, lost my hair after 2nd cycle.. It is upsetting and initially nothing is going to make you feel better.. I remember before I lost it I went to try wigs on and ended up sobbing. I bought a wig and had it trimmed by one of the Trevor Sorbie trained hairdressers ( see www.mynewhair.org ) which made it look much bettter.. I had shoulder length hair which I did not have cut beforehand. It started coming out in strands and then when I washed it the whole side came away.. As it looked so ridiculous I did have it shaved.. I know its hard to imagine but it actually looked better afterwards.. I used to wear the wig out and bandana/scarf indoors.. To be honest it was quite liberating when I was feeling not great just to come out of the shower and put the wig on.. I dont think i could have been bothered to have blowdried it !! I now have my hair back (completely different style and colour !!) and I do sometimes moan when I have to get up earlier to blowdry it !!.. I had a pretty good reaction to chemo, did recover very well each time.. Just remember to tell Doc any side effects as they can give you something..  Without being rud eif you are under 60 you need to apply for the Prescription Exemption Certificate.. Just fill the form in at your Doctors and they normally send it off. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Janet, You are very welcome..  You are going to get wobbly moments.. But you will come out of it the other side appreciating everything more !!!  I am due to see the Oncologist at end of May for my 6 month check and will start to fret a bit.. i think we will all be like that forever now.. Also sometimes its easier to talk to people on this forum as we are all in the same boat.. i think sometimes we dont want to say to much to our nearest and dearest in case of upsetting them.. Anything else just ask.. Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Carole You are welcome, to be honest once mastectomy was over I just felt it was out of me. I am really pleased with reconstruction. My surgeon did not want to do recon straight away as he thought I would need radiotherapy. On the last op he did a reduction, uplift on other breast and nipple recon on breast. I am really well, just take Tamoxifan tablets now for 5 years. Only see Oncologist every 6 months now. One of the things I struggled with was when I was diagnosed I had hardly ever gone to doc/hospital and was suddenly there all the time. When I had chemo I lost my hair and wore a wig. To be honest now when I have to get up 30 mins earlier to do my hair I miss that wig !!!! Just remember to do your excercises after operation. You will most likely have a drain in. I had mine in for 7 weeks!!! I just put it in a bag over my shoulder !!! Let me know how you are.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel How great for you all !!! I have a 10 year old Border Collie.. When I was having chemo in 2010, she was amazing. Before that she used to wake me up in the morning but when I was in bed after treatment she just used to lie by the bed until I was ready to get up. It used to make me feel better when I could take her for a walk. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Ali I had chemo last year and like you had shoulder length hair that I blowdried etc.. I did not have the Cold Cap so was expecting it to come out.. I did wear a wig, I was recomended to have the wig trimmed by a specialist.. If you look at www.mynewhair.org it is a charity set up by Trevor Sorbie (the hairdresser) who had a relative go thru this.. You can make an appointment with him either in Brighton or London.. I had an appointment with him but it was just after my 1st chemo and I was a bit unsure about travelling to london.. The website has a list of hairdressers in your area that specialize in the cutting of the wig. When I had mine done it did look quite different to when I had bought it. When I was having treatment one of the ladies had the Cold Cap, her hair also came out quite a bit, but did stop so she still did have a lot of her hair. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Donna, First of all you are not sounding like a moaning minnie !!! I started losing my hair after 2nd chemo, it was not to bad first of all but when I washed it the whole side just came away (can still remember sitting on the bathroom floor sobbing)..Because it looked ridiculous with tufts just sticking up i decided to have it shaved. I went to the hairdresser to have the wig trimmed and asked him to do it.. he was great as he took me into a side room and even asked if I wanted the mirror taken down. I know you might find this hard to believe but because it looked so stupid it actually looked better when it was shaved.. It did continue to grow very slightly, but nothing to get excited about.. How excited was I 3 weeks after last chemo when I could feel it growing !!!..  I am now 3 haircuts along and have a completely different hairstyle and colour..  I did used to wear my wig when i went out but wore scarves or bandana indoors. My only dislike of the wig was that it does make your head hot.. get some Johnson Baby wash to use in the shower/bath... Sending big hug.. Love Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Donna, So pleased that you bit the bullett !!!  I felt exactly the same when I had my head shaved..  It does feel strange but is a relief that you have dealt with that part.. You wait when you just jump out of the shower and just have to put on wig/scarf !! its quite liberating !!! Well done.. Love Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi Janet, i think once you have the treatment plan it helps you to focus more.. I had a mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy last year. I was told from the beginning really that I would have chemo because of my age (46).. My Oncologist recomended me to have it. The chemo was not as bad as I thought.. I did recover very well from it every 3 weeks. I did lose my hair and I wont lie it is very upsetting BUT try to focus on the fact that 6 - 8 months of treatment is hopefully going to give you many more years.. I finished treatment in June 10 and returned to work late July after having 7.5 months off. I feel really well and am hoping to have a reconstruction operation later this year.. I did have a wig  -which for me was the best thing.. Have a look at www.mynewhair.org which is very helpful. Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: Hi I had 6 sessions of FEC last year.. I was like you with relatively mild side effects but the Taxotere did really make me feel horrible.. Constipation was in far the worst as it made me feel so ill.. Thats funny you saying that about your skin as mine was like that.. probably was the best its ever been.. Dont really recomend it as a skin treatment !!! I did feel very weird but once I finished I did start to feel more like my self.. I think we all have real bad days and thats why this site is so good as you can let off steam without upsetting anyone..  I started radiotherapy 3 weeks after last chemo and that was a doddle compared to chemo !! it used to make me laugh in the waiting room as all the ladies who had not had chemo were moaning about how horrible R/T was and the rest of us thought it was great.. I finished treatment in June 09 and went back to work in July.. Do feel really well and am just coming up to my 3rd  haircut !!! Hope you soon start to feel better.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Urgh - feeling rough :(

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel How great for you all !!! I have a 10 year old Border Collie.. When I was having chemo in 2010, she was amazing. Before that she used to wake me up in the morning but when I was in bed after treatment she just used to lie by the bed until I was ready to get up. Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Leigh Well done with the eggs !!!! I had same chemo as you in 2010. Was not half as bad as expected. I did feel rough the 1st week but soon improved and by 3rd week was bombing round the shops. Whatever your side effects YOU must tell your Oncologist as they can change them or give you something. My worse side effect was Constipation. I found it better to have a light lunch before I went and then just some soup when I got home. I was never sick and found effects did not kick in for a few hours. When you have Tax you have steroids so you feel ok for first couple of days. Big hugs and good luck. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Nine eggs on ice!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Carole I was diagnosed in Nov 2009, I was told immediately I would need a mastectomy. Had that op 2 weeks later. Thn had to wait for 3 weeks for results. Was then told 2 out of 9 lymph nodes were infected so was recommended to have chemo & radiotherapy. Started chemo 3 weeks later ( 6 sessions of Fec). I had a good reaction to chemo and did not feel so bad. Then had 15 days of RT. I waited a year and then had LD Flap recon. Which was amazing. I then had "boob job" on other breast. I found this was the worst time. Once treatment started I felt more in control. Pls ask if you want any more info. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: Hi Carole My Surgeon loves his drains !! Most people don't have them in that long. They say if you are losing less than 40 -50 mls it can come out. I was losing about 350 mls initially. It's what they call a " closed wound drain" so you come home. I had to have the District Nurse in and also had to see my Breast Care Nurse. As I said it was fine. Take a bag into the hospital and once you are able to get up just put them in the bag. Normally the Breast Nurse will give you a leaflet with excercises to do. I was then referred to physio which I went to for about 6 weeks. You wil probably see Breast Nurse and Physio whilst still in hospital. Take care Love Debra Xx
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: Hi All I was diagnosed in 2009, had MX, Chemo & RT.. Was off work for 7.5 months so for last 4 weeks had to claim ESA as SSP had run out. Whilst not as mind boggling as Dougs it still was a performance and a half. Jessica, make sure you send Medical Certs via Recorded Delivery. I did that and was told they did not have them until I produced the Recorded Delivery details.  I then got a snotty letter telling me I had to attend "A Back To Work Interview" I phoned them and asked why ?? as I had a job that I would be returning to. I told them as I was returning to work in next couple of weeks I would not attend. They said that was fine..  Then got a really really snotty letter about not attending. I then complained in writing and sent copy to MP.. Got standard crap letter apologising. This illness is difficult enough to deal with without dealing with all this crap.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: A warning for those of you involved in work programmes

Posts.Content: Hi I am about to have this procedure on 28.06.13..  I had a reconstruction operation without implant but after reduction on other side was right.. Have been waiting a long time for this op as it is a new op for NHS. Will let you know how I get on. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Has any one had experience of fat transfer to 'fill out' the defect

Posts.Content: Hi, First of all aplogies.. I knew there was something I had to do !!! Operation went really well, my leg was really black and blue for a couple of weeks. They gave me thigh length compression stockings but I had been told that if I wore the slimming shorts from M&S that would be fine. It takes 2 - 3 weeks for cells to grow. Its very weird as it does grow a bit everyday. Unfortunately for me I need a bit more so am booked in on 27/09 for a repeat procedure. I am really pleased with the difference it has made and would highly recomend it.. Hope that helps.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Has any one had experience of fat transfer to 'fill out' the defect

Posts.Content: Hi Liz Hope you are ok....  I know how scary it all is...  Had my mastectomy Dec 09.. Had chemo and radiotherapy and have been back to work since July.. Anything you want to ask, dont hesitate... Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Sheena I had mastectomy, chemo & R/T last year..  When I was diagnosed I had the scan a week later and then op 5 days after that. When I got the results they took 9 nodes and 2 were infected although there was no spread anywhere else.. I think that apart from dealing with the diagnosis when you have never really had to go to the hospital throughout your life thats scary in itself ..  You are then confronted with all these appointments and tests. My Oncologist wanted me to have chemo more as a precaution and they like to start it about 6 weeks after operation. I think that when time pass's you will be grateful for the speed and the care you have received.. At the moment its all so scary.. Hope you get on ok today... Love Debra
Posts.Title: CT and bone scans

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, Glad you are coping, it is very difficult.. But definitely helps hearing from people who are/have going thru the same. I think the pamphlet re the excercises tells you the ones to do whilst in hospital and when you still have drains in. My nurse said best one was to do was like brushing your hair. I would imagine its quite difficult to wear a bra when you still have the drains in, I think I put one on about 3 weeks after the operation. I saw my nurse 3 days before operation and she gave me what they call a "comfy".. It has like cotton wool in so you take out or add to match your other side.. I was told I could wear this with my normal bra and sellotape a couple of 10p pieces to weigh it down. Personally I preferred to wear it with a proper mastectomy bra, as I found it moved around.  Yes the bra has a pocket  that you put the prothesis in. When it comes to the proper prothesis I was amazed how much time is taken over it. They like to wait till about 6 - 8 weeks after the operation (so any swelling has gone down). You are then measured exactly the same as other breast.. To be honest you would never know the difference now. They told me that if I put on weight/lose weight I can go back and have another fitting. I had to have chemo that started 6 weeks after operation. I have lost my dad to cancer 6 years ago and when he had chemo he was so poorly  - so I was absolutely dreading it. But in fairness it was not as bad as I had imagined. I was poorly 1st week, bit better 2nd and feeling relatively well the 3rd. Honestly - this was the worst time before the operation.. I remember leaving work the day before the operation and sobbing as I drove my car out, wondering if I would ever come back !!! Dont hesitate to ask anything else you want... Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Zena,   I had 6 sessions of chemo and then 15 days of radiotherapy...  R/T was a doddle compared to chemo.. I know what you mean about getting your life back but I thought I had come this far and another 15 days of treatment was bearable... I finished R/T and then had about 4 weeks further off work.I have been back since July now and feel really well... I am back to hospital on Monday for my 4 month check... Am getting a bit jittery but suppose I will always feel like that now.. Take Care Love Debra
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, Debra again !!  thought I would reply in correst post !!! I was never advised that I would be eligible for a Blue Badge when I had my mastectomy. My Mum has one  - due to walking problems and we have just renewed her one. Looking at the form I cannot see that you would get one. In fact my friend has MS and she has been refused one on the grounds of she does not suffer all the time with the illness.. Hope that helps Regards Debra
Posts.Title: blue badge

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon My name is Debra, I was diagnosed in Nov 2009, I had a mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy. I finished treatment in June this year and have been back to work since end of July. I am hoping to have a reconstruction op next year. I know exactly what you meant about "being in a fog" from when I was diagnosed it was 2 weeks later that I had the op. I did work up to the day before, and now when I think back I I must have been in a daze. On the morning of the op I was pretty calm and luckily was 1st patient to be operated on. From when I woke up I just felt it was out of me !!. I never had any pain at all from the op, just had paracetemol and anti-inflammatory medication. I was up and about the next morning. I assume your breast cancer nurse has given you info on excercises ?? there are some that you can do immediately after operation. I religously did mine and have never had any problems with my arm. One thing I say is once you are up and about they will put the drains in a bag. I got a chair and put it by the side of the bed so the bag rested on that and I was not worried I would kick it off the bed in the night. My surgeon let me come home with the drains (which I was pleased as one drain stayed in for 2 weeks).I just had the District Nurse come in everyday to look at it. I was told I could drive after 4 weeks. My nurse said if I could do a 3 point turn without any pain then it was fine. I had the proper prosthetic fitted about 8 weeks later, and although I will be pleased to have the reconstruction op, the prosthetic is so good, no-one would notice. One blessing about having it this time of year (I had mine in dec 09) is that you wear coats and jumpers so if you dont want to wear a bra initially its not a problem. I would say to you to buy the proper mastectomy bra. Mine were from a company called Royce - which I got from Debenhams online. Best of luck for the op and if you want any more info please dont hesitate to contact me.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon Hope all goes well on Monday, I had to be in at 7.30 but went down at 9.00.. So with all the visits and questions it went pretty quick.  When I woke up I was attached to a morphine pump and saline drip. Both of these came off the next morning.. When I wanted to wee the nurse initially gave me a bed pan but I could not use it so got up and used a commode..  It was the best feeling in the world the next day when I could use the proper toilet !!! If your husband does visit you straight after, you are in a gown and blankets over you so no-one can see anything..  I did not want my Mum to come with me beforehand but she got herself in a right state so she did come..  As I was a long time in recovery she came and sat with me there.. Although I was a bit dozy I was pleased she was there.. It will probably make him feel better if he can see you. Will be thinking of you on Monday. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Sheena Thats great news with your scan.. I have learnt enough about this disease to know its not necessarily where you get it its where its spread to which is the problem.. I had the Fec Chemo and I must say it was not half as bad as I thought.. Just remember not to fight it.. When you want to sleep just do it !!! I did lose my hair and wore a wig.. It was very upsetting when I lost my hair but I just thought I am going to have 6 - 8 months of crap and hopefully will save my life...  I will tell you that now my hair has grown I do sometimes moan when I have to blowdry it in the morning !!! it was quite liberating just jumping out of the shower and putting the wig on.. My treatment was also fantastic, I have seen a few posts on this forum where it has not been the same for a lot of women.. Keep strong and just deal with everything day to day.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: CT and bone scans

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies I was in the class of 2010 !! 5 years on and doing very well. I know it is so daunting when you start this journey but it's amazing how quick it goes !! I lost my hair with Chemo, since it grew back I have never really been that happy with it.. Tamoxifan has not helped and it's quite fine and thinning - especially on the crown. I have spent an absolute fortune on hair products in last 4 years and whilst some have been better than others, none I gave been really happy with. Whikst looking at Marks and Spencer Website I saw a 3 Step System from company called Swell. They did a trial size for £23.00 for shampoo, conditioner & root complex. So I bought it not really expecting a lot of difference. But I am so pleased with it. It took 3-4 washes for my hair to look better. It has much more volume and stays in the style for longer. My hair also looks thicker at the roots. It is not cheap but for me it has improved my hair. You can only buy it in certain M&S but can order from website. Amazon also sell it. Thought I would just pass this on.  Regards DEBRA
Posts.Title: HAIR AFTER CHEMO !!

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, I hope you are feeling calmer now... Please dont stop reading and contributing to the forum.. I was fortunate that I discovered a strength I did not know I had before the operation. And as I said to you before once I came round I just felt it was out of me.. But everyone is different.. I hope you decide to do the right thing for you and your family.. Love Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, When I was having chemo some lady told me I would be eligible for one.. Knowing the application process from my Mum i thought she was wrong.. This site is great for mostly non judgmental replies !!! I am well, seeing the Oncologist this afternoon for my 6month check-up.. Fell fine but getting a bit jittery now.. Suppose we will all be like that forever now.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: blue badge

Posts.Content: Hi I had same op as you last year..  Had a reduction, uplift & nipple recon 5 months later.. I am really pleased with it and it does look real.. Hope that helps.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Nipple Re-construction?

Posts.Content: Hi Angela, Hope you are feeling ok.. I was very surprised you came out so quick, I was in for 5 days.. If the wound is filling with fluid you will have to have it drained. I kept my drains in for about 10 days after op.. I still had to have the wound drained after a couple of weeks which was fine.. No pain just a bit uncomfortable.. I did not have any pain and as you say was very alert when I came round.. Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: New to group- so scared of whats to come...

Posts.Content: Hi Sally Hope you are doing ok....  I was diagnosed in Nov 09 had mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy. I had 7.5 months off work and came back last July.. Am really proud that have not had one day off sick since coming back.. Chemo is hard to deal with, I was very fortunate that I did not have to many side effects, and by the 3rd week was out and about everywhere.. I lost my haor after 2 nd cycle. They do have the cold cap where I was treated but I did not want to be in the hospital for a minute longer than I could help !!!  I did have a wig which was great   (to be honest now my own hair has grown I do sometimes moan when I have to get up earlier to do my hair !!).. I was advised to have the wig trimmed by a trained hairdresser.. I would assume that before you start chemo you will have a meeting with the Nurse to go over the side effects.. Just remember they have to warn you about all of them.  Remember to get a form from your Doctors to apply for free prescriptions. Anything else you want to ask, dont hesitate...  This is the worse bit - but you will come out of the other side.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: New to group- so scared of whats to come...

Posts.Content: Hi Angela, I am sorry I did not see this till this morning..  I hope all goes well with your op.. When I had a mastectomy (Dec 09) I had no pain at all..  Just remember to do your excercises.. I will tell you that the time before the op was the worst.. Once I had the op I just felt it was out of me.. I had 6 sessions of chemo and 15 days of radiotherapy.. I did have a wig which for me was the best thing.. My hair came out after 2nd chemo and I then went to a hairdresser who specialises in cutting wigs. He shaved my head and then trimmed the wig.. I was like you I did get upset when first trying them on.. Now my own hair has grown back and you are exactly right I now moan about getting up 20 mins earlier to do my hair !!!  it was quite nice with the wig just jumping out the shower and putting it on !!! Good luck and let us know how you are... Regards Debra
Posts.Title: New to group- so scared of whats to come...

Posts.Content: Hi Claire   I had 6 sessions of FEC Chemo, followed by 15 sessions of RT, which started 3 weeks after last chemo.. I was a bit like you, as I had concentrated so much on chemo that had not really thought about RT. I personally found it a doddle compared to chemo. I religously put on the Aqueous Cream and had no problems at all. I did feel tired but that was to be expected. The only thing I found was that sometimes it takes them a while to get you in position (by the end I could recite the measurements !!) and your arm may ache a bit afterwards. They give you the times at the beginning but I found if I wanted to change one there was no problem as long as I let them know with a bit of notice. I had two tattoo's   -which I cannot now see.. It is a pain going everyday  - I was fortunate as hospital wa sonly 5 mins drive away. I used the simple soap and shower gel and that was fine. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: Hi Claire   I had 6 sessions of FEC Chemo, followed by 15 sessions of RT, which started 3 weeks after last chemo.. I was a bit like you, as I had concentrated so much on chemo that had not really thought about RT. I personally found it a doddle compared to chemo. I religously put on the Aqueous Cream and had no problems at all. I did feel tired but that was to be expected. The only thing I found was that sometimes it takes them a while to get you in position (by the end I could recite the measurements !!) and your arm may ache a bit afterwards. They give you the times at the beginning but I found if I wanted to change one there was no problem as long as I let them know with a bit of notice. I had two tattoo's   -which I cannot now see.. It is a pain going everyday  - I was fortunate as hospital wa sonly 5 mins drive away. I used the simple soap and shower gel and that was fine. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: Hi Had chemo in 2010 - FEC, and the injections..  Also had lower back pain, and as been mentioned we all get a bit paranoid with every ache & pain !!!  I did speak to my Oncologist who said " its the injections stimulating the bone marrow for white cells" Hope that helps Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Lower Back Ache

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane, I had mastectomy, chemo & radiotherapy in 2010. I was very fortunate to have full sick pay for the whole time so I was off 7.5 months. The problem with chemo as apart from how it affects you 7 - 10 days after is when you are most susceptible to infection and that can be the dangerous bit. I am sure you have already been told if your temp goes up past 38 deg you must go straight to A&E. I think as its so close to end of term it might be better to take the time off. Saying that I had a really good reaction to chemo and by the 2nd week I was much improved. Having the summer holidays will give you a good indication of how your body will react. Regards Debra x
Posts.Title: About to start chemo .a question or two..?...

Posts.Content: Hi Annie Thats great news for you !!! Although I had Surgery before Chemo I was just so pleased " to get it out of me"..  You will feel much better after operation.. Glad you got to speak to "top dog Oncologist".. I have been very fortunate to get a great Surgeon & Oncologist from day 1..  You should just make it clear you would rather see this Dr if possible. Good luck Regards Debra
Posts.Title: never thought would be so happy to have surgery!!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, So sorry you are having a bad time.. I had amazing treatment from hospital and BCN.. I get really annoyed thats not the same for everyone.. If I was you I would contact the Oncologist Secretary to arrange a follow up appointment.. When I finished my treatment in 2010 I saw Doc every 3 months and have now graduated to every 6 months. Especially as you say you have had problems with your heart.. Hope the relaxation course helps.. Just feel free to vent your feelings !!! Regards Debra
Posts.Title: A bad day at the office

Posts.Content: Hi Julie & everyone else... I was diagnosed in 2009, had mastectomy, chemo & RT.. This is the worst time. Once they have got your correct diagnosis and you have a treatment plan it becomes easier to deal with. I remember feeling so ill and convinced it had spread but my Nurse said it was shock. Once I had the operation I felt "IT" was out of me.. I like you was told from the beginning the Surgeon thought it was 99% cancer. I could have hit him then - lol..  Now I think he is amazing.. Treatments are not easy, I was one of the lucky ones and had hardly any side effects from chemo.. Try to make a list of questions you want to ask as your brain goes to mush !!! Like Sue said - dont google.. Now I am fine, feel really well and dont really think about it a lot now.. Good luck Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - feeling lost

Posts.Content: Hi Michele, I had FEC in 2010. My hair started coming out after 2nd chemo. I thought like you it would come out on the pillow. I noticed when I brushed it, there was lots of hair flying about. When I washed it and then dried it with a towel the whole of one side just came away. I was upset but in the greater scheme of things it was not to bad. Hope you get on ok. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: When can I expect hair loss with FEC

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, When I had my wig cut I got hairdresser through. www.mynewhair.org They have a list of salons that have been trained to deal with hair loss through chemo. I did not use the cold cap so knew I was going to lose my hair. I did contact Toni & Guy local to me to ask them how much they charged to shave my remaining hair and trim the wig. I was astounded when they quoted £50 to shave my hair and £40 to trim the wig. I went to another hairdresser's which is not a cheap shop. They charged me £20 to do it all. I was so pleased with them that I have continued to go there. Hope this helps. Sorry no paragraphs as IPad does not seem to like them Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Wig business

Posts.Content: Hi Girls, Was diagnosed in 2009, had mastectomy, chemo, rads..  Waited a year then had recon..  Just need "some tweaking" on reconstructed breast now... Yes it is strange when you finish treatment, It really got to me when I was diagnosed that going from someone who never went to hospital to suddenly always there.. And then at end of treatment you are sort of in limbo..  I now just go for my 6 monthly checks..  I do get  agitated when that draws near - but think that will be the same forever now.. None of us know the future, but since I was diagnosed I have lost 2 friends to Cancer (ovarian & bone).. Both of them were fobbed off at GP's and by the time they were diagnosed it was to late. I thank god that my GP was on the ball and I received amazing treatment. Hopefully we will all be kept a close eye on so if anything rears its ugly head it will be dealt with.. Good luck with all your treatments. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: What now ?

Posts.Content: Hi Have a look at. www.mynewhair.org It was set up by Trevor Sorbie, you can go to his salon in London or Brighton. He has set up a training scheme for hairdressers to learn how to cut wigs. They have lists of local hairdressers that do this service. Oncologist signs form and they send it to the relevant department. I had a voucher for £60 but could use it as part payment. Could only use it in 2 shops though. My wig was short, I just went to local hairdresser. He then shaved my head and then styled the wig so it's more personal to you. Any more info let me know. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Wig business

Posts.Content: Hi Abbey I had Chemo in 2010..  I was never offered a Port or Hickman line.. Whilst I had very good reaction to Chemo I have had so many problems with accessing my veins when have had  a Reconstruction and other procedures.. So I wish to god I had been given the option of having one. I think we all feel like that upon diagnosis.. I found it became easier once treatment started as you then felt it was all being dealt with.. Good luck Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Worried about having a hickman line...reassurance needed please!

Posts.Content: Hi All I had chemo & RT in 2010..  I did have the full 7.5 months off work -  but have excellant sick pay so did not have to worry..  I was a bit grotty first week and then improved greatly after that..  By the end of the 3rd week I was hear, there and everywhere..  If I had to have gone back to work I would have been ok half way through 2nd week and 3rd week.  You obviously have to be very aware that 7 - 10 days after chemo you are more susceptible to infection so do need to be careful.. As previously said everyone is different so you will have to wait to see how you react.  I have known people be so ill after first chemo but when Doctor changes medication they have improved greatly for subsequent ones.. Hope that helps Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Will I be able to work through treatment?

Posts.Content: Hi Sue Welcome to the club no-one want to join !!! I had chemo in 2010, you do get paranoid every pain you get..  I am sure if all your tests have been clear its just a frozen shoulder.. I would mention it to the Oncologist, more so to put your mind at rest. Hope you get on ok with rest of treatment. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Possible bone mets but nobody listening to me!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey, I had mastectomy, chemo and rads in 2009/2010. My Consultant did not recomend immediate recon as I was to have RT. A year later I had LD Flap Recon, beforehand I had asked if it could be done without an implant (not that I had an issue about that but just though something else to go wrong). I was told I could have as long as I had a reduction on other side. I know what you mean about "perfectly healthy breast" but felt best option for me. So 4 months after recon I had the recon. When I woke up I could see there was still a significant difference. I was then told that breast can only be reduced so much as otherwise it goes out of shape  -  as you can imagine I was not happy as if I had been told that I would have had the implant.  I then had to wait over a year for my Health Authority to get the Lipofilling Machine. I had 2 operations for that  -  3 months in between. Although it made a difference the original recon had moved towards my arm.. Doc decided to reposition the reconstruction, I had that op in March this year and am so happy with results. So to answer your question I dont think its anything to do with your friend being a Nurse, its dependant on Doctor & Health Authority. When I had Lipofilling it was taken from my leg, but can be from tummy buttocks etc.. I think you have to try to pursue the Lipofilling as it does make a difference. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: breast augmentation.

Posts.Content: Hi I had Mastectomy in Dec 2009,  I was advised by Surgeon to have a delayed reconstruction. I had Chemo & RT in 2010 and then a year after treatment finished I had a LD Flap Reconstructon. I asked for this without implants (if possible) as I just thought this was something else to go wrong. Surgeon said that was fine as long as I had reduction on other side. So thats what happened, I recovered well from Recon op. Had no real pain and got movement back pretty quickly. Had reduction later in 2011. Unfortunately I was never told that the breast can only be reduced so much otherwise it will go out of shape (I would have had implant if I had known that) So Breast was still significantly smaller than other one. I had 2 further lipofilling operations last year which although made a diference was still not enough. So finally in March this year Surgeon repositioned the reconstruction and I am very happy with the results. You will be offered a prosthetic to wear before Reconstruction. To be honest I was really impressed with the level of detail that went into the fitting of this, and it looked great. Despite the delays in sorting this I still feel it was the best decision for me to have a delayed reconstruction. Regards DEBRA
Posts.Title: Immediate versus delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Annie My Oncologist told me I could have 2 units of alcohol a week. I was a bit scared with reaction to chemo but it was fine. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Alcohol

Posts.Content: Hi Gill, Glad you are beginning to feel better...  I had chemo followed by RT in 2010.. I personally found RT to be a doddle after chemo..  I slapped on the Aqueous cream religously and had no problems with actual treatment. Make sure you do your arm excercises as you have to keep your arm in one position, and whilst the actual treatment was only minutes it does take some time to get into right position. It does make you tired but (if this makes any sense) its tired tired not ill tired like chemo !!. I now take Tamoxifan, (since 2010) and again have had no side effects.. Make sure you have sorted out your Free Prescription form with GP.. Anything else , please ask.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Radio Therapy and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Janet. I had this op in Dec 2011. I stayed in one night but to be honest could have come home same day. Was all fine had no problems. I had op on a Friday and was driving on the following Wednesday. Would think you will be fine for your event. Just take it a bit easy. Debra x
Posts.Title: I am booked in for my uplift/reduction on good side. What is the recovery...

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine, I think we all struggle with this predicament. I had MX, Chemo & RT in 2009/2010. My Mum lives with me and she does not drive. During the treatment I was pretty well so all " the offers of help" I did not have to see if anyone meant it A year later I had a Reconstruction Op and although I recovered well from it I was pretty poorly with anaemia and drain still in. A week after the Op my Mum had a Mini- Stroke.i called the ambulance and of course had to go with her. Don't think A&E knew who to treat first !!! Anyway one if my Aunts kept saying " if we need anything just ring" so I did and asked them whether they could come to hospital as I felt so unwell and be with Mum. They told me " sorry, had something on ". I think the next day they regretted what they had said. Must admit never really forgave them for that. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: your thoughts please-help should I have to ask or should it be offered...

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn I also had back flap recon but about 18 months after mastectomy. Am really pleased with results. I did not have hardly any pain from both ops. I was advised to buy a surgical front fastening bra that was put on after recon op in theatre. It was a Royce Lingerie bra. The bag does get a bit heavy, although I found it was better when there was a bit in it as it weighed the bag down better.Also when she leaves hospital get as many of the drain bags as she can as District Nurse never seem to have enough if them. Make sure the District Nurse organises the Clinical Waste Collection through the Council. One of my best things in the hospital was a little portable radio that I could listen to in headphones so did not disturb anyone else. It's a difficult time for all if you. But I just felt hundred times better after mastectomy when I felt it was out of me. This website is so great as there is always someone to answer a question or just to have a moan !!!. Sorry no paragraphs as IPad does not seem to like them !!! Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn Glad you found the Royce Lingerie Site worth looking at. I bought most of my bra's from there. I hope your daughter gets on ok tomorrow. I am sure she will feel better once operation is over. Meant to say that she is likely to have a Morphine Pump attached when she comes out of Theatre. I only used mine once ( and that's when I got confused with light switch !! Lol). Good to have though. She may also have a catheter in. It's not a bad thing as you don't have to keep getting up for the loo. Mine came out after a couple of days. Not sure if she is due for chemo and or Radiotherapy. I had a really good reaction to chemo and did not have a lot of side effects. Yes did lose my hair but in the greater scheme of things that was not so bad. I was reading your messages to my mum.. She hopes you are ok as she found it very difficult to deal with. Good luck and let me know how she is. Tell her we expect an update !!!! Love Debra.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn Glad she was ok this morning.. When I had my mastectomy both Mum and I were sobbing as they carted me off.. I was in Theatre for 8 hours for the Reconstruction, its a long op.. Think its better for the patient as they just shut their eyes and when they open them its all over.. When you ring later it may be worth asking whether you can go to Recovery to see her.. When I had the Mastectomy they told Mum she could come in there.. When I had Reconstruction she was told I would be back in Ward about 7.00pm so she got a taxi.. Sat in the Ward for a couple of hours and then Surgeon came to see me and he took her down to Recovery to see me. One of the weird things with the Recon is that it has to be kept at a warm temperature for a few hours after op.. I woke up to find, what I can only describe as a tumble dryer hose in the bed attached to a heater !!!  it was soooo  hot (as it was July). I had to ask them to turn it off as it was making me feel sick. My Mum did find it difficult, we had lost my Dad 8 years before to Cancer so when I first found the lump I did not tell her until I was diagnosed.. I think in retrospect that was a mistake as that upset her even more.. Once your daughter has had op you will feel better.. Chemo normally starts approx 6 - 8 weeks after Surgery. To be honest you are better dealing with one thing at a time. Once she is feeling better you will have the information meetings to go through it all. Hope she is ok (and you of course !!).. Love Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Good Morning Ladies, I was diagnosed in 2009, had mastectomy. chemo, RT, Recon - I was 46 when diagnosed.. I started taking Tamoxifan in 2010, like most people my periods stopped during Chemo, had no further periods. In January 2013 I started bleeding slightly - nothing major so did not take to much notice. About 1 week later I suddenly had the most awful vaginal bleed, it lasted for a couple of days and then stopped completely. It did freak me out so I went to see GP. He said immediately I had to be referred to the hospital as any unexplained bleeding after not having periods for so long has to be investigated. I was even more shocked when I received phone call 2 days later for the appointment the next day at the Gynae Oncology Unit !!. By this time you can imagine how I was feeling, anyway went  hospital. Although Doc could not feel anything abnormal she said I had to have further tests a week later as they have to treat this as a possible recurrence.. So had an Ultrasound & Probe ( believe me BC Tests are sooo much more dignified !!). I then saw the Consultant a couple of days later. She told me that my Womb lining had thickened so they had to do an examination with a camera. She told me straight away that there was nothing suspicious but the Tamoxifan had caused Womb Polyps  - some had broken away and thats what had caused the bleeding. As you can imagine I was relieved. I was then booked in for a Womb Scrape, couple of weeks later. I spoke to my Oncologist who was going to change the Tamoxifan but my Estrogen Levels were to high. I have had a few incidents of bleeding since, so have been told the Polyps are growing again. So I would urge any of you that have had unexplained bleeding to get it checked out. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Periods returning

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I had mastectomy in 2009 and then reconstruction operation last year. My body " loves" drains.. After MX they were in for 2 weeks and after Recon was in for 7 weeks !! So became a bit of an expert !! As previously said you need short sleeve front fastening PJ!s. I got mine from M&S, Per Una. When you come round from operation drains will be attached to side of the bed. Once you are up and about I found best thing was a canvas bag from Primark that had long handles. You can pop drains in there and put bag on your shoulder. When you sleep get a chair beside the bed and put drains on that. So you are not worried about knocking them off. Once you come home district Nurse will come in to change bag and calculate the loss. It has to be less than 40 mls to come out. I had no problems at all with them. After Recon I just put them in bag and went out and about. Hope this helps, anything else please ask. Regards. Debra xxx
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly Yes you are in the right place !!!  dont want to be like the rest of us !! Just to tell you a bit about me, I was diagnosed in 2009 had mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy. All treatment finished in 2010..  I am now really well and feel fine.. This is the worst time, once they have agreed a treatment plan you know where you are..  Of course its normal to be shell shocked.. I remember a few days after diagnosis I went into complete shock and was convinced it was everywhere.. I lost my amazing Dad in 2004 to Cancer.. That I think made it worse initially as all I kept thinking about was him.. The treatments are amazing now.. I was told that if you were unfortunate enough to get this insidious disease Breast Cancer is the "best" one to get !!!..  Yes I did lose my hair in chemo but I felt to put up with 6 - 8 months of feeling crap that would hopefully entail me to live a lot longer its worth it.. Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: I'm new and just been diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn Glad all is ok. Same thing happened to me with loss of blood during operation. It's good they are giving her a transfusion so quickly as they left mine a few days and I felt awful. Was loads better after transfusion. I also had to take iron tablets for a few weeks after. Hope you are ok !!! Love Debra
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy I was diagnosed in Nov 09, had mastectomy followed by chemo and radiotherapy.. I am hoping to have a reconstruction operation next year. To be honest for me the worse part was between diagnosis and the operation.. I got myself in such a state, everytime I had a pain I was imagining it had spread everywhere.. I had a long chat with my Breast Cancer Nurse and she said it was shock.. Once I had calmed down I felt better in myself.. Once I had the op I just felt it was out of me..I recovered very well from op and started chemo 6 weeks later, which although was not great I coped with it very well.. In my area (Essex) the operation has to be carried out within 4 weeks of diagnosis.. I waited 2.5 weeks... I was at a group meeting last week and a young girl 27, was there she also carried the faulty gene and had opted for a double mastectomy.. She was doing really well and just baout to have a reconstruction.. If anything you want to ask please dont hesitate.. Love Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy Glad you are coping, it is very difficult.. But  this site will help you as everyone has or is going through the same as you. Thats great news scans were clear.. I had a CT Scan 5 days before the operation. I was absolutely terrified of the results as I lost my lovely Dad to cancer 6 years ago and he was diagnosed through a CT Scan. I asked the surgeon the morning of the operation, luckily all was okay..  I have learnt with this illness its not necessarily where you get it, its where it gets to... My surgeon did not want me to have the reconstruction straight away as he wanted to see if I needed further treatment.. I did have chemo and radiotherapy.. I will tell you that I had absolutely no pain at all from the operation. I was on a morphine drip when I woke up but that was taken away the next morning as I did not need it. I was up and about the next morning.. As I said before I feel really well.. I am back to see the Oncologist this afternoon for my 4 monthly check.. Feeling a bit jittery today bit think I will always feel like that now.. Hope you get your genetic results in time... Take Care Love Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy Hope you are okay... Thanks for the email...  Yes it was fine..  Oncologist gave me a thorough examination and dont have to see him again for 6 months.. Just remember this will be you in a years time !!!  I decided on the way to the operating theatre last year I was going to do something really nice on that date a year later.. So I am off to see Oliver the Musical in london and then out for dinner in Covent Garden.. Take care Love Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Kate, I hope that you and your family are coping... I was diagnosed Nov 09, had mastectomy, chemo and radiotherapy. This is the worse bit.. The waiting for answers. Once I had the op I felt it was out of me. I had a better reaction to chemo than I thought.. I lost my lovely Dad to cancer 6 years ago so for my poor Mum it was a terrible shock. So I can imagine how you are feeling about telling your parents. On the subject of your friends, you find out who are your true friends !!! a colleaugue of mine at work has been absolutely wonderful even though we were not that over friendly beforehand. I lost my hair after 2nd chemo, I did buy a wig beforehand and for me personally it was the best thing. I do think you have to deal with each stage as it comes. if you are having op first deal with that.. I was told before the op that they would have no results until 2 - 3 weeks after. I then saw the Doc and was told they recomended chemo and r/t. I had 7.5 months off work, went back in July and I have been really well.. Have had no lasting side effects from the treatment. I am hoping to have a breast reconstruction op next year. As you seem to have realised whatever your worry/query there is always someone on this site with some advice.. Take care Regards Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, Hope you are coping okay.. When I had my operation, I was told i would not be told any results until 2 -3 weeks after the op. I then saw the consultant, i think they have a meeting beforehand with Oncologists to discuss treatment. They took 9 lymph nodes and 2 were slightly infected.. Also did a auxillary clearance and was graded at 2. That was on the wednesday and I was given an appointment to see Oncologist on following Monday. He felt that the best course of treatment was chemo and radiotherapy, mainly due to my age (46).. They like to start chemo no later than 6 weeks after surgery. I did lose my hair and had decided to buy a wig beforehand..  Which for me was the best thing as I did not want people thinking about what I may have had.Everyone is different and you do whats best for you. I am still wearing it and have just made a hairdressers appointment for Dec to have my own hair done !! what I will say is that it was quite nice when I was not feeling that great just to come out of the shower and put my head on !!! I did find its best to deal with each stage as it comes along. So wont go into chemo (apart from was not half as bad as I thought) until you know what your treatment plan will be.. Take Care Love Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy Only just saw this email....  Sorry you wont have read this before your op... Hope all goes well and you are soon up and about.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Green Giant, Hope you are ok...  I had surgery first (mastectomy) and then chemo and R/T.. Must say chemo was not as bad as I was expecting... You must just remember to tell the Oncologist of the side effects and hopefully they can give you something to alleviate symptoms. I did not use the cold cap, and lost my hair on 2nd session. I had bought a wig beforehand. Everyone is different and you must do what makes you more comfortable. Some ladies dont wear anything or just a scarf. For me I did not want people to know what I had unless I told them. The wig was great, I am still wearing it and hoping to have my hair cut and styled in next few weeks.. Its nothing to do with being shallow. If you feel comfortable with how you look it will make you feel better.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: The wait from diagnosis to surgery

Posts.Content: HI OWLCITY I was diagnosed in 2009, had mastectomy, chemo, radiotherapy. Then in 2011 I ad a breast reconstruction. I feel really well now and have just had my 3 year all clear. It is a hard thing to deal with. I think sometimes its worse for the relatives as you don't quite know what to do or say. I had FEC Chemo and although I was very lucky in my reaction to it it still made me feel pretty awful. Just be there for her. And think of the great Xmas you will have next year !! Love DEBRA XX
Posts.Title: Help.

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera I was diagnosed in 2009, had my Mastectomy on 4th Dec 2009 !!! Was then followed by chemo and rads. Like has been said before its not easy but we get through it. I had 9 lymph nodes taken & 2 were infected. This is the worst time, when you have the op you will feel so much better the cancer is out if you. I am now 3 years on and yesterday got the all clear on my 6 month check up. I feel really well and all seems a long time ago. Please ask I anything you want. Sorry IPad does not like paragraphs !! Regards. Debra xx
Posts.Title: Finding it hard to cope

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha,   It must be very difficult for you with no BCN where you are.. I was diagnosed in 2009, have had mastectomy, chemo, radiotherapy, reconstruction  etc !!!! if you want to ask anything pls do... Regards Debra
Posts.Title: Getting there

Posts.Content: Hi Irene, Do you normally have your bloods taken at hospital couple of days before chemo ??  if so this is when they will decide whether the count is to low for chemo.. Regards Debra
Posts.Title: neutropenia

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian Thanks for that... I will ask the Oncologist about that this afternoon.. Glad you are doing well.. I will probably need you on speed dial when I have the recon !!! Regards Debra

Posts.Content: Hi Girls I had 6 sessions of FEC in 2010, followed by radiotherapy.. I like Tinkers had a pretty good reaction to Chemo, felt not that great first week, bit better 2nd week and relatively normal 3rd week !!! It does scare you all the known side effects but everyone is different.. I  cant really add more advice than Tinkers has done but as she said make sure you tell your Oncologist of every side effect.. I had bad indigestion but Doc immediately prescribed me something to take..  My worst side effect was constipation.. I used to have a swig of the mouthwash everyday and although mouth felt a bit furry !!  I never had any ulcers.. Make sure you take the prescribed anti-sickness medication, even if you dont feel sick YOU MUST continue taking it for the course. If you are going to have Taxotere (normally last 3 cycles) just be aware you take steroids for this just before chemo and whereas FEC has an effect within hours Taxotere (for me) took a couple of days to kick in.. Listen to your body and if you need to rest make sure you do..  I did struggle a bit with improving over the 3 week period and then knowing I was going to be unwell again.. But its a means to the end !! I then had 15 days of Radiotherapy, which was a doddle compared to chemo..  Since then I have had a breast reconstruction, then an uplift and reduction and am going into hospital this friday for an implant to be fitted.. It took some time to recover from treatments (and hair to grow lol) but now I feel really well.. Good luck Regards DEBRA
Posts.Title: starting chemotherapy........

Posts.Content: Hi Pollycat Not sure whether these injections are same as ones I had..  They were to stimulate white cell count after chemo. Took them 5 days after chemo for for days. If they are the same, please dont worry about injecting yourself.. It really does not hurt.. just remember to alternate injection site. Normally you inject into your tummy so just do alternate sides.  I was a bit wary about preparing the needle but once I had done it a couple of days it was fine.  Had no side effects apart from aching lower back.. As we are all paranoid about every ache and pain we get.. I did ask Oncologist and he said its "where the bone marrow is being stimulated to produce white cells"..  I never once had a low bllod count and am sure was down to these injections. Hope this helps. Regards Debra
